supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes the need for integrated and multisectoral actions, recognizing the strong correlation between human health and animal health.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, such as strengthening clinical, microbiological, and pharmaceutical surveillance.
The NAP outlines actions for the surveillance of antimicrobial resistance in animal health and production agroalimentaria.
The document does not specify actions targeting the environmental sector directly.
The NAP addresses the regulation of antimicrobial use in agriculture and food production.
The NAP establishes a National Commission for the Control of Antimicrobial Resistance to verify compliance with the approved strategy.
The document does not specify time-bound targets.
The NAP does not provide quantitative targets for AMR prevalence or antimicrobial use.
The document does not mention any specific budget allocation.
There is no assessment of future budget requirements mentioned in the NAP.
The NAP creates a National Commission for the Control of Antimicrobial Resistance.
The NAP includes regulations for the use of antimicrobials in both human and animal health.
The NAP mentions incorporating AMR topics into the curricula of health sciences.
The NAP proposes campaigns to raise awareness about the responsible use of antimicrobials.
The NAP acknowledges the need for international collaboration in addressing AMR.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of strengthening surveillance systems for AMR.
The NAP includes actions for the early detection and reporting of emerging resistance.
The NAP outlines strategies for infection prevention and control in healthcare settings.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes regulations for the distribution and prescription of antimicrobials.
The NAP promotes the rational use of antimicrobials through regulatory measures.
The NAP encourages participation in international research collaborations for AMR.
